chapter.title: TIF provides guidance on integrating transition skills to ABE
chapter.content:
The Transitions Integration Framework, or TIF, was developed by the ABE Teaching and Learning Advancement System (ATLAS) at the Hamline University School of Education in Minnesota. TIF is the outcome of a collaborative of adult basic education and ESOL teachers and professional development specialists, with the goal of advancing transitions instruction in Minnesota.

Like the Employability Skills Framework, TIF provides guidance to adult educators on how to integrate transition skills—essential academic, career, and employability skills—into all levels of adult basic education (ABE).

This topic introduces TIF and describes training materials and key features.

chapter.title: TIF's six essential professional skills align with workforce preparation activities
chapter.content:
TIF identifies six categories of essential professional skills that are well-aligned with workforce preparation activities. For each category, the skills and subskills are outlined in terms of observable behavior that indicates students have obtained the skill. The acronym SWBAT, which stands for “students will be able to,” precedes each skill, followed by a description of what the performance of that skill looks like. Read an example of one skill in the Navigating Systems category, below.

TIF AT a Glance

Navigating Systems (NS)

In aggregate, the skills in all six categories reflect a comprehensive inventory of essential skills that adult educators need to integrate into their instruction to help learners transition successfully to postsecondary education, career training, and the workplace.

chapter.title: Key features of TIF
chapter.content:
Some of the key features of TIF are:

  • Sample classroom activities (not full lessons) for each of the six skill categories and a subset of the skills;
  • Sample activities along a continuum of three levels of increasing complexity but not tied to specific educational functioning levels;
  • Examples for integrating technology into activities. The technology activities are also presented on a continuum of complexity;
  • Guidance on how the sample activities can be modified to apply the skills to community, school, and work contexts;
  • A table illustrating the alignment between TIF skills and the College and Career Readiness Standards; and
  • An “At-a-Glance” checklist (pg. 49) to guide curriculum planning. It can also serve as a tool for students to help identify needed skills and track progress towards skill attainment.

More Information

ATLAS provides a variety of additional Academic, Career & Employability (ACES) resources to help teachers apply TIF, including sample lessons, webinars, and videos.
